body:
I feel it should be pointed out that Ruqqus has a leg up in the sense that most of the Gender Critical/TERF crowd wound up at Saidit and they're now on their way to being Feminist Voat. Voat is kneecapped by their user base and if Saidit becomes too overwhelmed by 4th wave feminist rhetoric, they're going to chase off all their more normal users.

Ruqqus is the only one out of the three that, for the moment, doesn't have a dominant group beyond the memers. At best it has a somewhat right leaning majority, but anything less than total anarcho-communism is now 'right leaning', so I'm not even sure that means anything.

Edit: I personally think you guys are doing great and the site is shaping up nicely.

body: To anyone intimidated by the wall of text, the video its transcripted from is more digestible. Not to suck the admins' cocks too hard, I do have to say that it has been very refreshing seeing them act in a collected, calm, and intelligent manner on everything official. In a world where being an emotionally charged admin is commonplace, keeping a level head is a rare sight. Really insightful response to the ama!

body:
---end of transcript---

There is a third thing I'd like to add to the discussion: User-powered filtering.

Other social media platforms infantilize their users, spoon-feeding them only "acceptable", politically correct, vanilla content. We see this with the Twitter trending section. They routinely purge the Trending bar of anything that might be sensitive or offensive, leaving it as a perpetual mix of boring trash and Orange Man Bad. We see this with Reddit's redesign, pushing paid promotions and other intellectually bankrupt content to the forefront of the site.

Ruqqus takes a different tactic, giving users the power to decide for themselves what they wish to see. All of the content filtering options are user settings, and are off by default (with the sole exception of the NSFW filter, which is active by default for legal reasons).

At Ruqqus, we don't spoon-feed you "safe" "acceptable" posts. We let you choose what you want to see.
body_html:
---end of transcript---

There is a third thing I'd like to add to the discussion: User-powered filtering.

Other social media platforms infantilize their users, spoon-feeding them only "acceptable", politically correct, vanilla content. We see this with the Twitter trending section. They routinely purge the Trending bar of anything that might be sensitive or offensive, leaving it as a perpetual mix of boring trash and Orange Man Bad. We see this with Reddit's redesign, pushing paid promotions and other intellectually bankrupt content to the forefront of the site.

Ruqqus takes a different tactic, giving users the power to decide for themselves what they wish to see. All of the content filtering options are user settings, and are off by default (with the sole exception of the NSFW filter, which is active by default for legal reasons).

At Ruqqus, we don't spoon-feed you "safe" "acceptable" posts. We let you choose what you want to see.

body: That seems to be the price of websites built off of the free speech platform; you get /pol/tards. /pol/tards will always take advantage of websites that pride themselves on free speech. They'll create their own echo-chambers on said websites, try to gate keep or 'set the record' in comment sections outside of their echo-chamber, then scream 'censorship!' at anyone that tells them to fuck off back to their own sub/guide/whatever. You of course get some Tankies in the mix, but they mostly stay on Reddit, Twitter, Facebook and the other popular social media websites.

body:
You summed it up perfectly describing Voat and SaidIt. Voat has all of the degenerate assholes while SaidIt is just a Reddit clone. It has a similar name, swapped the r/subreddit for s/subsaidit, and copied the look of Old Reddit. It's a soulless clone through and through. Ruqqus tries to be different with a neat UI, good people, transparency by the admins, and the admins try doing what's best rather than what Reddit does/did. 

Ruqqus has a soul and wants to be an alternative, not a clone.

body:
>Addressing the Voat problem: our initial userbase, dating back to the very earliest days, was not people who were trolling assholes who got banned for a reason. Voat's initial userbase was trolls that got banned for a reason. Our userbase was not. Our userbase, from the very beginning, has always been people that are relatively normal, and are just pissed off at the state of censorship in social media, and Reddit in particular.

Believe it or not but Voat's userbase used to be super left wing. I was there. It still turned into a hard right echo chamber and Ruqqus is no doubt doing the same.
body_html:
Addressing the Voat problem: our initial userbase, dating back to the very earliest days, was not people who were trolling assholes who got banned for a reason. Voat's initial userbase was trolls that got banned for a reason. Our userbase was not. Our userbase, from the very beginning, has always been people that are relatively normal, and are just pissed off at the state of censorship in social media, and Reddit in particular.

Believe it or not but Voat's userbase used to be super left wing. I was there. It still turned into a hard right echo chamber and Ruqqus is no doubt doing the same.

parent.body:
---end of transcript---

There is a third thing I'd like to add to the discussion: User-powered filtering.

Other social media platforms infantilize their users, spoon-feeding them only "acceptable", politically correct, vanilla content. We see this with the Twitter trending section. They routinely purge the Trending bar of anything that might be sensitive or offensive, leaving it as a perpetual mix of boring trash and Orange Man Bad. We see this with Reddit's redesign, pushing paid promotions and other intellectually bankrupt content to the forefront of the site.

Ruqqus takes a different tactic, giving users the power to decide for themselves what they wish to see. All of the content filtering options are user settings, and are off by default (with the sole exception of the NSFW filter, which is active by default for legal reasons).

At Ruqqus, we don't spoon-feed you "safe" "acceptable" posts. We let you choose what you want to see.

body:
***** 5 Star Review

I've never used reddit or any of the other reddit like sites you mentioned so I have no basis for comparison, all I know is those sites didn't interest me but Ruqqus did for some reason. Great site, it's easy to use/navigate and has broad userbase from across many a spectrum (take that as you will).  I'll never see another 503 in my life and not think Ruqqus... A devious marketing/branding ploy indeed. 


Seriously though, 503s are part of the community/Ruqqus lore at this point and even though they frustrate us we kinda love them, or at least I do. Gives the ol' dumpster arsonists something to look back in a few years when Ruqqus is huge and has millions of users. We can sit back and relax peacefully in our Endless Summer recalling the heady days of the 503s.

Keep up the good work guys.

body:
Frankly, I believe the others failed due to lack of moderation.   Moderation is not censorship, or at least it should not be, good moderation just keeps things on topic and interesting.  

Without any moderation, an internet forum will ALWAYS devolve into a dumpster fire and the trolls control the conversations and everyone who was originally interested in the original topic gets bored and leaves.   
Seriously, we learned this in the early days of the internet forums, PhpBB, IRC, etc.  Not sure why we need to keep learning this.

parent.body:
>Addressing the Voat problem: our initial userbase, dating back to the very earliest days, was not people who were trolling assholes who got banned for a reason. Voat's initial userbase was trolls that got banned for a reason. Our userbase was not. Our userbase, from the very beginning, has always been people that are relatively normal, and are just pissed off at the state of censorship in social media, and Reddit in particular.

Believe it or not but Voat's userbase used to be super left wing. I was there. It still turned into a hard right echo chamber and Ruqqus is no doubt doing the same.

parent.body:
Frankly, I believe the others failed due to lack of moderation.   Moderation is not censorship, or at least it should not be, good moderation just keeps things on topic and interesting.  

Without any moderation, an internet forum will ALWAYS devolve into a dumpster fire and the trolls control the conversations and everyone who was originally interested in the original topic gets bored and leaves.   
Seriously, we learned this in the early days of the internet forums, PhpBB, IRC, etc.  Not sure why we need to keep learning this.
parent.body_html:

Without any moderation, an internet forum will ALWAYS devolve into a dumpster fire and the trolls control the conversations and everyone who was originally interested in the original topic gets bored and leaves. Seriously, we learned this in the early days of the internet forums, PhpBB, IRC, etc. Not sure why we need to keep learning this.

body:
Yanking posts is a really cool feature but are there any plans to go further? Reddit kind of has crossposting but it would be cool to be able to see comments on the same link/post on differne guilds or even interact with them.

All of this being said I'm concerned at the viability and effectiveness for a reddit style forum (branching comments, reply notifications, post decay) to effectively scale. Even at the moment the discord is a key part of the site and caters to many users. 

I'd be interested in hearing your thoughts on different [communication models](https://social.antefriguserat.de/index.php/Social_Platforms) and moderation techniques (twitter/mastodon, facebook/disporia, 4chan/2ch, hacker news/lobsters, ceasefire (originally change a view), Google+/mailing lists/forums) and if you're planning on implementing any of their ideas?
body_html:

body:
I think thwre should be two voting systems on Ruqqus as well.

One of the voting button pairs is meant to vote on whether something adds to the discussion, while the other pair is for your own personal opinion on it.

Example:
"Owning any gun is bad because X, Y, and Z"

Upvoted in the first pair as serious and contributing to the discussion. Downvoted in the second pair for not being agreeable.

body:
> One's called White Beauty, one's called Black Beauty. I think it's called Black Beauty, it might be called something else. Anyways, they're both intentionally very wholesome, very family-friendly subreddits, just showing pictures of people having fun, smiling, enjoying a picnic with their family, whatever, maybe clothes modeling or what have you. One of them's all for white people, one of them's all for black people, but the white one is quarantined as offensive racist hateful content, because it promotes white people in a positive light. Which is not something you can do nowadays. That's not politically correct anymore.

That's crazy. I have never heard of either of these subreddits (or the situation). The 'white beauty' subreddit is now banned. At least r/whitebeauty; you may not be talking about that one. 

> For example, on reddit, there are some detailed technical reasons why you cannot change the capitalization of a subreddit, or a username, after the subreddit or user account has been created. Because other things link into that, and if you change the capitalization, it breaks those links. And then the site breaks.

This is also crazy. It makes no sense from a user perspective; I understand technically if things aren't set up in the best ways it makes sense. Thank you for making this a possibility!

Re: what you said about Voat and Saidit:

You completely nailed it. I think Voat will maintain that image of 'being racist' for at least a little while longer, if not forever. Saidit **will** stay a 'reddit clone'. If you took away the logos, no one would know the difference between Saidit and [old] Reddit. The name does not help whatsoever.
body_html:
One's called White Beauty, one's called Black Beauty. I think it's called Black Beauty, it might be called something else. Anyways, they're both intentionally very wholesome, very family-friendly subreddits, just showing pictures of people having fun, smiling, enjoying a picnic with their family, whatever, maybe clothes modeling or what have you. One of them's all for white people, one of them's all for black people, but the white one is quarantined as offensive racist hateful content, because it promotes white people in a positive light. Which is not something you can do nowadays. That's not politically correct anymore.

That's crazy. I have never heard of either of these subreddits (or the situation). The 'white beauty' subreddit is now banned. At least r/whitebeauty; you may not be talking about that one.

For example, on reddit, there are some detailed technical reasons why you cannot change the capitalization of a subreddit, or a username, after the subreddit or user account has been created. Because other things link into that, and if you change the capitalization, it breaks those links. And then the site breaks.

This is also crazy. It makes no sense from a user perspective; I understand technically if things aren't set up in the best ways it makes sense. Thank you for making this a possibility!

Re: what you said about Voat and Saidit:

You completely nailed it. I think Voat will maintain that image of 'being racist' for at least a little while longer, if not forever. Saidit will stay a 'reddit clone'. If you took away the logos, no one would know the difference between Saidit and [old] Reddit. The name does not help whatsoever.

parent.body:
---end of transcript---

There is a third thing I'd like to add to the discussion: User-powered filtering.

Other social media platforms infantilize their users, spoon-feeding them only "acceptable", politically correct, vanilla content. We see this with the Twitter trending section. They routinely purge the Trending bar of anything that might be sensitive or offensive, leaving it as a perpetual mix of boring trash and Orange Man Bad. We see this with Reddit's redesign, pushing paid promotions and other intellectually bankrupt content to the forefront of the site.

Ruqqus takes a different tactic, giving users the power to decide for themselves what they wish to see. All of the content filtering options are user settings, and are off by default (with the sole exception of the NSFW filter, which is active by default for legal reasons).

At Ruqqus, we don't spoon-feed you "safe" "acceptable" posts. We let you choose what you want to see.

body:
>Saidit [are] now on their way to being Feminist Voat

That's a weird way to spell Raddle. I literally forgot all about it, and apparently everybody else did too, until I read that line. Raddle was one of the early-ish r*ddit alternatives that was even **more** far-left than reddit, to the point that one of their top communities is literally called "race", and it's exactly what you have in mind...

Sad to hear about Saidit though, I kinda liked their retro-looking interface and responsiveness, shame they're on the reddit path already. Thankfully we still have Ruqqus!

parent.body:
I feel it should be pointed out that Ruqqus has a leg up in the sense that most of the Gender Critical/TERF crowd wound up at Saidit and they're now on their way to being Feminist Voat. Voat is kneecapped by their user base and if Saidit becomes too overwhelmed by 4th wave feminist rhetoric, they're going to chase off all their more normal users.

Ruqqus is the only one out of the three that, for the moment, doesn't have a dominant group beyond the memers. At best it has a somewhat right leaning majority, but anything less than total anarcho-communism is now 'right leaning', so I'm not even sure that means anything.

Edit: I personally think you guys are doing great and the site is shaping up nicely.

body_html:
The ironic thing is that Reddit's entire structure - a large collection of self-governing communities - is theoretically the best IMO.

Individual communities about specific topics, ran by people who care about those topics and want to see their communities thrive. Overall site-wide governance aimed solely at legal and ToS compliance. What could be better?

Reddit completely fucked up a fool-proof system by:

  1. Allowing the ability of individuals to moderate excessive numbers of communities;
  2. failing to hold moderators accountable;
  3. tipping the balance by holding different communities to different standards.

parent.body:
Frankly, I believe the others failed due to lack of moderation.   Moderation is not censorship, or at least it should not be, good moderation just keeps things on topic and interesting.  

Without any moderation, an internet forum will ALWAYS devolve into a dumpster fire and the trolls control the conversations and everyone who was originally interested in the original topic gets bored and leaves.   
Seriously, we learned this in the early days of the internet forums, PhpBB, IRC, etc.  Not sure why we need to keep learning this.

I can't and won't speak for anyone else, but I appreciate the fuck out of it.

body:
> Honestly, I wish we had thought of it. That- That is something they definitely did right, that two different kind of upvotes, that's something they did right for sure.

Fark.com had that for... a decade? Other sites like Ars Technica have done that as well. I don't think that's their idea.

> And it drove away all of the regular everyday Joes, and attracted more racists, and more antisemites, and more neonazis. 

It is sad to see people believing that this is really a thing. Like the whole "nazis" thing at the "unite the right" rally. They were carrying flags... that all had the creases still on them. Because they had been recently purchased and handed out at the rally. Why would a "real" neonazi not have a nazi flag? One that they hung up in their house or whatever, to bring with them to the rally? Because they were paid actors, so the media could say "look at all these nazis at the right wing rally!" despite them not really existing.

Like if I'm going to go to a rally and bring an American flag, I'd take the flag off my flagpole out front. It has no creases on it, because I didn't get it from the guy paying me to attend, and am an actual American.

Antisemitism is an easy topic. You have the GOP that supports Israel, and the DNC that wants to destroy Israel. The people who want to destroy the Jewish ethnostate are... you guessed it... antisemites.

And lumping fat people in with all that, is just extra bad. You know that "average, ordinary joes" love making fun of fat people, right? Like, why do you think Eddie Murphy (Big Mama's House) and Tyler Perry have movie careers? Why do you think we had MULTIPLE movies about Paul Blart, mall cop? Ever seen Austin Powers? People of Walmart and ugly people dot com were around before reddit, facebook or twitter. Making fun of fat people is as American as apple pie and is a core pillar of the internet.

> Voat's initial userbase was trolls that got banned for a reason.

> that was something I knew about because I've been very involved in the moderator community and the default moderator community, pre-Ruqqus.

If you've been involved in that community, then you know bots drive most of reddit. Most of the default sub content is posted autonomously, as is the social media content of most companies in the world. There are billion dollar social marketing platforms in the enterprise space and have been for over a decade at this point.

The reason why "reddit killer" sites suddenly get "content problems" is because these same tools used to run reddit are used to keep reddit with the lead marketshare. Any time a competing site gets on their radar, they engage bots to spam the shit out of it with content they can then use to cancel the entire site. This was largely originally built to cancel subreddits they needed an excuse to ban, but now they don't really even bother with that.

And that's where ruqqus is actually different. It's not a clone of reddit, so these tools can't just plug and play into ruqqus to spam the shit out of kiddie porn and whatever else. It will take time for them to build up the automated tooling to achieve the same result. The question is, can ruqqus gain enough steam before that happens to drown it out, or catch it early enough to ban it out. 

That's what you should be thinking about. Work on a plan to address it.

body:
I love the work you guys have been pouring over this website. Seriously, props to all three.

Since captainmeta4 mentioned the Coven Of Witches problem: I've noticed the witches became far more common over the last month. While I don't think this is a problem on its own\*, avoiding a takeover might be tricky; let's be frank, the alt right loves censorship as much as AHS does, except they try to enforce it through different means.

This might be a thing to solve in the future. So far this is already looking great.

\*while the alt right discourse is stupid, its presence actually increases the diversity of the place, provided it's unable to displace other discourses.

parent.body:
---end of transcript---

There is a third thing I'd like to add to the discussion: User-powered filtering.

Other social media platforms infantilize their users, spoon-feeding them only "acceptable", politically correct, vanilla content. We see this with the Twitter trending section. They routinely purge the Trending bar of anything that might be sensitive or offensive, leaving it as a perpetual mix of boring trash and Orange Man Bad. We see this with Reddit's redesign, pushing paid promotions and other intellectually bankrupt content to the forefront of the site.

Ruqqus takes a different tactic, giving users the power to decide for themselves what they wish to see. All of the content filtering options are user settings, and are off by default (with the sole exception of the NSFW filter, which is active by default for legal reasons).

At Ruqqus, we don't spoon-feed you "safe" "acceptable" posts. We let you choose what you want to see.

---end of transcript---

body:
Y'know, the thing I hate about reddit the absolute most is that I'm pretty well in the center, politically. I'm pro 2A, pro federal legalization of marijuana, I don't give a fuck who you marry, I think Trump has done some great things and I think there are things he could have done better. I'm also for some police reform and although the BLM organization sucks, obviously, black lives matter because all lives do.

But because I'm not super hardcore on any of those stances, you're either a "boot licker nazi" or some "liberal cuck".

I've found the conversation here to be more reasonable and more open to both sides.

>Saidit [are] now on their way to being Feminist Voat

That's a weird way to spell Raddle. I literally forgot all about it, and apparently everybody else did too, until I read that line. Raddle was one of the early-ish r*ddit alternatives that was even **more** far-left than reddit, to the point that one of their top communities is literally called "race", and it's exactly what you have in mind...

Sad to hear about Saidit though, I kinda liked their retro-looking interface and responsiveness, shame they're on the reddit path already. Thankfully we still have Ruqqus!

body:
I feel obligated to say something.

My only potential concern moving forward is relative to the communities that we don't necessarily want. It has been made explicit through everyone's comments, including your own, that you want to discourage racist/xenophobic/nazi or otherwise hateful and/or inflammatory groups. I think this presents a challenge moving forward. Because this website's core purpose is anti-censorship, and ultimately providing a platform for open expression. I find it *very* improbable that these two conflicting ideas won't cause instability moving forward.

body: I think you have missed some of the issues around voat and that is the turbulent history of the website, like disabling community creation for example or going private. I don't think it's necessarily the reddit code base that is the problem but the likes of people like spez that allow communities to be destroyed and taken over and generally interfere with users on reddit. To me the fundamental problem with reddit is the moderation. You have attempted to address that technically but it is only a weak and not very good attempt. Ultimately ruqqus has as it's single point of failure like reddit does too that even if the policies and tech today are pro free speech then tomorrow it can all change and for that federation and distribution seems the only solution. Block chain seems interesting too. To me the silver bullet to defeating reddit is solving moderation, which ruqqus, nor saidit has done. The idea for the solution exists but still ignored sadly. Dividing content into communities is also a stupid idea. Often content is covering many topics and by limiting it to just one topic(guild,sub,etc) you are limiting it's potential to be upvoted and reach it's full potential. There are so many obvious things wrong with the so called reddit, sub, moderator, vote style system. Some are quite obvious to fix others not so. I don't think you have the right ideas yet here at ruqqus, I wish you luck but I am certain as you are now you will not bring down reddit. To me reddit will fall quite easy if you get the fundamentals about your site right from the beginning. Which is what rights your users should have. I would really like to say users have a fundamental right to free speech but no nation on earth allows that with so called "illegal speech". So a user should have as free as possible speech, the other right a user should have is to choose what they want to read or see and that means ultimately not having fixed moderation. No one individual should have the power to have the ultimate say over another over whether or not he can or can not see something, except the viewer himself. That is to say the ultimate power over moderation should rest in the reader,viewer or user. Until you can sit with these principles and some others and have them as a solid philosophy about what you want the site to be you won't be the reddit killer or ultimate platform.

body:
Thank you that explanation it really helps to build confidence in the platform to know the devs know what they are doing.

Now, I think the gate keeping of guilds behind 250 rep points dos not help with the Coven Of Witches problem you describe. 

You have relatively low guild count and most of thous guilds are of a "destructive comedic nature". I mean no offence by that description , love me some comedy, love me some memes, and sure as hell respect any one with that gut to trade punches with the current Establishment in any and all areas of life, we need different ways of thinking and by definition the uncommon opinions need to be more disruptive to be at the same level as the standerd believes .

This destructive comedic and sometimes just destructive communities produce mostly criticisms as a reaction to other content. This communities are not healthy per say as they are extremely mono-tone, one can only spend so many hours laughing and raging at memes in +ClownWorld.

What i mean to say is that **you need communities that are built and centered around more than a strong dislike of some other thing**.

* +WatchRedditDie - strong dislike of reddit
* +ClownWorld - strong dislike of sjw and some political causes with funny undertones
* +CancelCulture - strong dislike of cancel culture
* +RacistPassDenied - strong dislike of "equality politics"
* +WakeUpWhitePeople - wake up presumes need for some sort of "rebelion"

Each and very one of this guilds deserves there right to exist and to freedom of speech 

But by having the new guild creation locked behind 250 rep you only attract people who like this content, and who like it more then the stuff they can find in more popular sites with more normy content and more Original content can provide.

I understand the need to control guild creation but as it stands a miner that wants to create a guild about blue collar jobs or a danish that wants to create a guild about vikings or engineer that wants to create a guild to discuss news and improvements in the airplane industry... all this people **need to post to the most popular guilds** to try and get rep to build there own.

this mean that hard working adult man as to spend time of his day commenting and reaction to "Orange man bad" or "Whites can be black if they wish" some of the top posts in +ClownWorld the most popular community excluding +WatchRedditDie. 

Sure i could go to +WatchRedditDie instead but **not every user as to hate reddit**. I by all means do. They shadow banned my account automatically when i only had made a few posts about some boring tech stuff, not funny, political, or offensive. Unless communication to the world you experience learning Git is now considered Offensive. Who know, maybe im the on in the wrong?  And on top of that they ignore all your request for an appeal. The pricks just hammer indiscreetly and don't even provide a platform to help correct the collateral damage.

Still despite my experience i dought that theres many normys out there losing sleep waiting for the demise of Reddit. The truth is I can't pull up this website on my lunch break at work and not receive a warning from HR.

Unless your plan on creating and auto moderating artificial commonalities you need to make the guild button more easily accessible. The guild creation is for people that **believe the platform** and not in the **current content**

> We need user that are not waiting for something or someone to die but instead that are ready to give birth to strong communities. - Gandi

>Saidit [are] now on their way to being Feminist Voat

That's a weird way to spell Raddle. I literally forgot all about it, and apparently everybody else did too, until I read that line. Raddle was one of the early-ish r*ddit alternatives that was even **more** far-left than reddit, to the point that one of their top communities is literally called "race", and it's exactly what you have in mind...

Sad to hear about Saidit though, I kinda liked their retro-looking interface and responsiveness, shame they're on the reddit path already. Thankfully we still have Ruqqus!

Sad to hear about Saidit though, I kinda liked their retro-looking interface and responsiveness, shame they're on the reddit path already. Thankfully we still have Ruqqus!
